instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message:
I've got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which the customer says just switched off. I've had a look under the microscope and there is no sign of any liquid damage to any of the components. It's been ultrasonic cleaned and after probing around I've noticed that all the AWAKE and SLPS2R rails are pulsing. These all come from the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. I'm getting a stable 3.3v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> and PPBUS is also stable 12.27v.

Am I correct in saying that the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is faulty or is there anything else that it could be or I could check.

Thank you in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message:
SMC/<SIGNAL>PMU_COLD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> stay low, or pulse?
Looks like no communication between T2 and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

Check for short at all <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> surrounding coils; also at any big coil from the board.

Did you try with known good batery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PMU_COLD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is also pulsing

Not tried it with a battery as I would have thought it would work fine with just the mains plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message: Some boards, don't turn on without battery...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message: With is showing 0amp I was a bit sceptical but tried it anyway. I used a brand new battery which has 60% charge on it and it's still showing 20v 0a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message: Do you syill get pulsing voltages (like before) with battery connected???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message:
Yes same as before.. I really can't think it's anything else than something around the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> or the chip itself. Do you know if this chip is firmware locked to the board?

I'm just waiting for the go ahead from customer to remove the shielding that covers the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. The other option will be to sending back to Apple for a replacement under the Consumer Law.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0amp
threads.message:
Check if machine is covered by some Apple warranty first.

"The other option will be to sending back to Apple for a replacement under the Consumer Law."
Sounds like best option...
